Others are like this too: TPL is short for TOPLESS. A very non-work friendly gene name to google. The mutant has occasional conversion of shoot meristem to root meristem, so the plant had double root & no shoot or "top". Interesting story but hides interesting molecular function.

Does it tell you that its biochemical function is as a kinase: noDoes it tell you that it has an interesting role in an RNA decay pathway (and maybe DNA repair): no. It does tell you that it was in an interesting mutant screen in worms. It is a history lesson.

In my PhD I discovered that plants have a functional copy of SMG1. The TLA comes from a C. elegans mutant screen for suppressors with morphological defects on genitalia mutants. Does that name mean anything to non-worm people: no.

Potentially unpopular opinion: I do not like the need to write out the "Full" gene/protein name rather than the TLA. Most gave silly names that do not reflect either molecular or physiological function in a given organism. But people expect to learn something from it.

Many thanks to @FRM_officiel @AgenceRecherche @IbeidLabex and our collaborators for numerous discussions esp. around satellites @jrpenades and defence systems @dbikard. By the way, P4 like satellites have lots of defence systems too: https://t.co/woWVuK0JRs

In short: phage satellites are widespread, abundant and characteristic mobile genetic elements. When a P2-like phage infects a bacterium it is likely to find a satelite waiting there. This affects phage-bacteria interactions and will shape their evolution.

P4-like are present across Enterobacterales (>10% of all genomes), sometimes show broad host range, and are probably very ancient. The acquisition of the pair of highjacking proteins Psu/Sid marked their genesis, even if some elements have lost Psu. https://t.co/5YCU0jsiA4

We were surprised by their abundance. Very few P4-like elts were described. We identify >1,000. Most w/ all core genes and P4 genetic organisation. In E. coli almost half of the genomes have at least one P4-like element somewhere in the chromosome. https://t.co/DwxHWhGMQN

What are they? P4 have been proposed to be plasmids or phages. They are none. They are integrative mobile genetic elements with a distinctive core genome and a few hotspots leading to an open pan genome. https://t.co/6k9Z7aTk9q

Bacteria have phages, phages have satellites: a complex tripartite interaction within the cell. While exquisite mechanistic studies unravelled a lot about satellites, little is known on their origin, gene repertoires, diversity and distribution. @doctor_jams now uncovers it all https://t.co/PD9BzTFvqM

However, if a process takes longer than overnight to finish, then I'll put in effort *while it's running* to try to speed it up.Even if I take hours or days to do that, I'm still likely to come out ahead after shifting it into a faster wait category and re-running.
If I think I can make quick tweaks to shift thing into faster wait slots, then I'll probably do it when I have a break in activity.

And then there's an "overnight" time slice, where I'll start something running at the end of a work day, go to sleep, and it's done by the time I get back to work. This is a good fit for long processor-intensive tasks, especially if they're not particularly time-critical.

Beyond that, up to a few hours, it becomes worthwhile to do a context switch and change to a different task, or attend a meeting. If something takes half an hour, or a couple of hours, it doesn't really change what I'd do while waiting for it to finish.

Beyond this, it's coffee / break time, up to about 20 minutes. I go away, do something relaxing, and by the time I come back the program is finished. Most recently, I've been using these time slices to start a 3D printing run, or fetch a completed print.

Beyond that, there's a stretching / entertainment time, up to about 2 minutes. Within this time frame, progress bars are helpful for entertainment while a program does it's thing. There's not quite enough time to distract my mind with something else, due to the context shift cost

I think about the waiting I do in terms of what can be done with the time.A program that runs and finishes before I can type out another command is usually the fastest I care about. I'd only care about optimising it if I needed to run it multiple times.https://t.co/Ib2oqjIbWT

So; Remember; Ethnicity - a 1 dimensional thing you ask patients or participants to tick defined largely by cultural convention; Genetics - a ~300,000 dimensional thing assayed using a genotyping array or a sequencing machine. Don't mix them up.

It doesn't mean genetics wont contribute - it might; it is non-random after all - but really you've got to go a long long way from a Mann Whitney test of self reported ethnicity to show a genetic effect.

So - what is going on when we see correlation? Well... your first thought should be the big hairy mess which is human society with all its complexity. It is obvious that ethnicity via these social effects has an impact... and the obvious thing is probably the most likely.

Furthermore humans are a weird species; we exploded out of Africa so insanely fast, and spend so much time travelling around and having sex (even before ships and aeroplanes) that we're basically one massive group of African apes, spread across the planet.

(This goes to fact that we don't nod knowingly with people with red hair and say "no, wait, really, which part of Ireland is your family from". We have put a set of visible characteristics as somehow important in classifications for cultural reasons... called it ethnicity)

We don't do correlations wrt to hair colour of some other disease and then start talking about profound genetic effects. It would be ... bizarre. As well as the dimensionality problem, the major "bucket driver" of ethnicity is just arbitrarily chosen wrt to genetics.

Furthermore, ethnicity is *really* keyed into visible differences, above all skin pigmentation, and this is just one trait. Honestly. It's not some magic thing. You might as well lump people by height or hair colour.

The two things aren't random (what is with a 300,000 dimensional space?) but that doesn't mean 1 dimension with 30 options can frankly do *anything* about prediction of 300,000 dimensions. Its... laughable.

The issues are a multitude, but the simplest is that self identified ethnicity is at best a choice of 1 from 30 odd boxes to tick (with the classic "Other" or "Mixed Race" box thrown in). Genetics is a ~300,000 independent dimensional dataset (formally 3 billion, but 300K blocks)

Self identified ethnicity is an apparently simple and "well understood" thing which actually is just a mess, *very* cultural defined - eg, "Black British" - and although non-random wrt to genetic markers *is nowhere near* a good proxy for genetics. Just - not even close.

Another nails-on-the-blackboard moment - for my clinical and research colleagues; a phenotype or disease being significantly different between self identified ethnicity (take your pick of framework; US or UK or Brazilian or German...) is *not* good evidence for a genetic effect.

People using the same word but meaning different things is such a massive thing and has always worried me. The potential for things to go pear shaped are endless! You‚Äôd think people would start any serious discussion by agreeing on the definition or meaning of the terms used.
*Also, pet peeve, ‚Äúecosystem‚Äù as used in bioinformatics, meaning a more or less arbitrarily defined collection of data, tools, resources, etc... üò¨

...which specifically refers to the *seasonal* cycle of dominant species in a lake ecosystem*, vs. long-term development of a community in ecology. (I was so annoyed when I realized. Here I am, about 25 years later...)

Thank you Bev Holmes and @Alisonh3 for your paper. It has  prompted an optimistic reflection of the work and the people that surrounds me who are absolute giants in #impsci #imppractice. As a budding implementation scientist I'm very excited for the future of our field. üôèü§ì

In a recent paper with @JanetCLong and team we outline rich pictures as a soft systems methodology tool to map out complex adaptive systems when implementing new scientific findings to avoid linear thinking at a system level. Collaboration with @AusGenomics https://t.co/il8QTP41fV

Taking this paper forward in my PhD on redesign and implementation of genetic and genomic models of care, combined complexity lens with PAR methodology and #impsci in a framework called SPAIR (presented at the UK #impsci conference 2020). Later this year we will report findings. https://t.co/lueX6XWKNc

‚ö†Ô∏èOpp 3: Bringing a complexity lens to implementation science- referenced here is the seminal paper by @JBraithwaite1 and team published during the first year of my PhD training under Jeffrey @AIHI_MQ. BMC Medicine, full Text here: https://t.co/rDNb0A3hMV https://t.co/XRKkquBG33

To further improve my #impsci #imppractice capacity building I am learning from the best in the business: @Julia_E_Moore @sob_khan @TCI_ca who have fundamentally shaped the foundations of my knowledge which I pass on daily, and use within projects across organisations üôè

We have #impsci expertise embedded into leadership-  @jfredlevesque leading the organisation and @kimlsutherland3 leading our Evidence Directorate, and more. We are also collaborate with @AIHI_MQ Implementation Science Interest Group community of practice led by @karenh071 & co.

....on another project with @jmonty_health collaborating with @nicole_rankin8n and a team at Sydney LHD, we are working on a research project focusing on strategy design for the implementation of standards of care post limb amputation. This will build #impsci capacity team-wide.

‚ö†Ô∏èOpp 2: Building implementation science capacity- @nswaci Clinical Implementation we have #impsci 101 sessions every 2 weeks, journal club type presentations on using methods, we are also working on #impsci research projects to understand capacity building and embedding....

....CFIR, COMB/TDF for assessment of barriers and facilitators, and 3 theories of change for different levels when we head into piloting and implementation, and evaluation of implementation outcomes (Proctor).

E.g. I am working on a new model of care with @nswaci Spinal Cord Injury Network to increase equitable access to specialised spinal acute care and rehabilitation. Here we are using Redesign Methodology with Intervention Mapping and Implementation Mapping as our process models....

‚ö†Ô∏èOpp 1: ¬†Embedding implementation science in health care- @nswaci Clinical Implementation team we have an #impsci action plan led by the support of our CE @jfredlevesque @jmonty_health to use #ImpSci methods, theories, and frameworks for the implementation of system redesign.

with more high-quality genomes, metabolic data and more. Thanks to all my coauthors and to @CommsBio. I hope our work inspires more folks to look at the very early stages of evolution and the origin of life with new eyes! (11/11)

bc ancient. We also found LBCA was most likely rod-shaped, had gluconeogenesis, RNA modifications and multi-functional enzymes. I am very proud of the steps we took here, but also look forward to those that will build up with more data and clarity that will emerge  (10/11)

We wanted more evidence that the 146 LBCA genes were widespread not because of LGT, so we compared the verticality (from another paper) of LBCA genes to all bacterial genes. We found that LBCA genes are remarkably more vertical, therefore most likely widespread  (9/11)

The signal was very strong towards #Clostridia, a Class of #Firmicutes, that is interesting bc it has one of the simplest forms of carbon and energy metabolism which many other lines of evidence say is ancient, the Wood-Ljungdahl or acetyl-CoA pathway. (8/11)

Then we looked at ALL rooted trees for ALL proteins for ALL those anaerobic organisms (filtering trees for quality) and quantified different metrics of #ancestry (+ statistical tests) to find: which modern groups are most similar to those early lineages of Bacteria?  (7/11)

families that were conserved in ALL the groups. These were 146 genes which surprisingly build a well-connected, nearly complete core metabolic network; expanded with just 9 genes the network included ALL universal metabolites for Bacteria. (6/11)

We looked at ALL the well-known bacteria that do not use oxygen, and the #taxonomic groups they are organized into. LBCA was born in a time without oxygen. This reduced phylogenetic noise considerably. We built gene families for those organisms, and found those  (5/11)

finding the original message in a game of telephone where not only there are random changes inserted in each transfer, but where new words are inserted by new players coming in the middle of the game! What did we do to deal with this mess? (4/11)

It has been really hard to decipher the deep #phylogeny of Bacteria, bc they are the largest and most diverse of all domains of life, and they are masters in LGT-lateral gene transfer-which reshuffles the #genetic content that is vertically inherited. Think of  (3/11)

LBCA and LACA were the ancestors of each prokaryotic domain, #Bacteria and #Archaea respectively. We know they must have existed, because there are marked and conserved differences between the domains - these helped us know more about LUCA in past work. (2/11)

We all know the Last Universal Common Ancestor LUCA, but what about her daughters? In our latest work we looked at the most puzzling, LBCA, and find striking similarities to her sister LACA, and more! A üßµ. #Biology #Bacteria #STEM #AcademicChatter https://t.co/ghcHfoHrNo  (1/11)

TBH, this might be a better path towards content regulation than expecting those who profit from proliferation of extreme content to regulate it.And if it came to court, I bet'cha discovery to discern who their funding sources are would be super-fun.We'll see.

A standard license template with a table at the end specifying restricted/prohibited content would be far better than one-off licenses... (actually, TBH, all licenses should be based on a standard template, and deviations from base should be called out for regular folk)

So if you see content that violates, you can send a archive+takedown notice to the host, and a bill to the entity involved in its production.And if it actually gets collected, put the bulk of the money towards mitigating the harm and/or monitoring for other violations.
And, as the end product is clear, most corporate IT departments won't have to worry about licensing issues for engaging in these activities.And it's easily presentable in court.

And for open source code, ensure that derivative works can not be used by those for those same purposes.This is different than the general "do no evil" licenses - this targets end users of media creation products, where the end product can easily be evaluated.

You decide what your labour helps create: don't want to support racism, misogyny?  Exclude videos that promote ethnic or national supremacy from free licensing structures.Anyone who uses your tech to make something noncompliant accepts whatever royalty structure you pose.

In Molecular Cell, Wang et al. describe genome oligopaint via local denaturation fluorescence in situ hybridization (GOLD FISH). This Cas9-superhelicase-based DNA-FISH method locally denatures DNA at physiological temperatures and provides an improved signal-to-background ratio.

And also I note - I have objected to / been scared of "gain of function" experiments with nasty pathogens for years - see some comments in this thread https://t.co/q118YgugFX so I am certainly not endorsing such work here ...

The "accidental release of a natural pathogen" theory, which is similar to many cases that have occurred in other places such as those detailed by @alisonannyoung in her article, is the one of the "lab origin" theories that I think is worth looking into the most
It is the "purposeful release" and "human engineering and then release" theories that do not seem to have any even circumstantial evidence to support them.

I would like to point out something many but not all know - there are multiple "lab origin" theories out there including purposeful release of natural pathogen, human engineering & then accidental release, accidental release of natural pathogen, and more

I‚Äôve struggled with an eating disorder ever since. it dictates so much of my everyday life. it‚Äôs better now than it has been in the past, but seeing shit equating one free donut to obesity sends me right back to my lowest spots. (7/)

I‚Äôm terrified of them. donuts, junk food, anything ‚Äúunhealthy‚Äù. my brain sees them as a slippery slope, as though eating just one will transport me back to my highest weight. my biggest fear was realized‚Äîmy weight had been holding me back. the world only opened for Skinny Me.(6/)

the world opened up for me‚ÄîI was perceived as more competent and more intelligent for literally no reason. it blew my mind. I had no idea the world was like this for skinny women. and ever since, I‚Äôve been so afraid of going back that I literally can‚Äôt eat donuts. (5/)

so I did. I lost nearly 100 pounds in the span of a few months through crash dieting. I also lost about half of my hair, but this didn‚Äôt matter to anyone. I was praised TO THE MOON for losing weight. suddenly boys liked me. suddenly I was perceived as quirky instead of weird (4/)

however, in my senior year of high school I got ghosted by my first boyfriend after he went to college. being a petty teenager, I decided to ‚Äúget hot‚Äù to get back at him‚Äîand at the time, to me that meant losing weight. (3/?)

I grew up fat. like, for real fat. I was classified as morbidly obese for most of my childhood. I was supremely lucky in that I was outgoing and friendly enough for nobody to really give me a hard time about it, at least not to my face. (2/?)

d. Do not pour any cleaners into unmarked containers for use elsewhere e. Cannabis edibles should not be stored with regular food (can be mixed up by substitute caregivers and unintentionally given to children as candy)

4)There are simple steps to take to protect children, including:a. Toddlers and young children should be supervisedb. Keep all poisons in locked cabinets, out of reach of childrenc. Medications should always be kept in childproof containers

3) New threats, including cannabis edibles, hand sanitizer and vaping liquids can cause significant harm to young children, and are often not thought of as poisons.  Prescription medications (esp. heart and blood pressure) (often from grandparents) can also be deadly to children

1) Unintentional poisonings are a leading cause of preventable pediatric death and injury2) With children spending much more time at home due to the pandemic, exposures to household poisons has increased

Shameless plug, but somewhat related:https://t.co/4KPks6nvaE

"Data on the number of updates to software tools from GitHub such as the number of versions, commits and contributors was significantly correlated with software accuracy"This is what matters: sustained development over time

"We found the lack of a correlation between software speed and accuracy surprising. The slower software tools are over-represented at both high and low levels of accuracy"I frankly don't: investing in the development should improve both accuracy and speed

"This implies that high citation rates for bioinformatic software is more a reflection of other factors such as user-friendliness or the Matthew Effect other than accuracy"The "market" for tools is very much winner[s]-take-all

"Our study finds little evidence to support that impact-based metrics have any relationship with software quality, which is unfortunate, as these are frequently cited reasons for selecting software tools"
"there was an excess of 'slow and inaccurate' software"

"Heuristic software such as BLAST, compromises the mathematical guarantee of optimal solutions for more speed. Some researchers may naively interpret this fact as implying that slower software is likely to be more accurate"Interesting, I'd never think of thinking this way
"In the absence of any recent gold-standard benchmarks, how should scientific software be selected?"

"Sustained software development, not number of citations or journal choice, is indicative of accurate bioinformatic software" by @ppgardne et alQuoted text is from MS [small edits for space], unquoted is mine

So while I really bought into the idea that someone should help them with their science and communications, and I do think I made some things better there with my advice, just  joining their SAB, even with the tiny role we had, was clearly a wrong decision. 9/n
So while I think I did help make some of their communications more sound, there were many other things there were doing, just in terms of communications, that were clearly unsavory. 8/n

In fact, one of the (many) reasons I stepped down from the SAB was that some colleagues told me uBiome was using my name in announcements / emails / etc somehow as evidence that all their claims were valid (and this was before the clinical tests). 7/n
Alas, what I was really naive about, and what I had not counted on, was that uBiome would use my being on the SAB as some sort of endorsement of all of their operations.  6/n
And they said OK and in my time on the SAB, most of what I did was give advice and guidance to people working on their communications about microbiome topics. 5/n

All basically said the same thing - something akin to "Well, they really need better guidance and someone from the community needs to help them" so I agreed to do it. And I told the uBiome folks that I wanted to focus on communications related issues 4/n

I note - I had been asked to be on their SAB after publicly critiquing the founders and some of their operations. I was very skeptical about joining and actually asked many of my colleagues and microbiome gurus what they thought. 3/n
In the case of uBiome, I served on their SAB for a little over two years and I think during that time there were maybe 2 formal SAB meetings. 2/n

In regard to this comment https://t.co/bpNbBO44C9 I thought I would add some more details.  Note - a Scientific Advisory Board (SAB) is really very different from a Board of Directors.  In my experience the role of SABs  is usually pretty minimal (e.g., 1-2 meetings / year) 1/n

Some references: ‚ÄúWhen English is not your mother tongue‚Äù (@Nature) Researchers across the world encountered gatekeeping and limitations of career prospects  when they did not master communicating science in English. 8/10https://t.co/ZP0jyyeUBl

The quality of English should be seen as a binary variable: ‚Äúis this paper reasonably understandable by someone who reads English?‚Äù, and not as a criterion for evaluating the paper's merit. Place the threshold as low as possible and kindly accommodate non-native speakers. 7/10

It is impractical and discriminatory to ask authors to submit perfect English papers. Not everyone can find a (near-)native English speaker to proof-read their work under stressful conference deadlines. 6/10

It might be helpful to disentangle language (style, grammar, spelling) from clarity (definition of jargon, flow of ideas,...). The former can be fixed at editing time. The latter can betray a flaw in reasoning or missing information. 5/10

Clarity should be judged on how ideas are articulated and organised, not on who checked the language in the paper at submission time. If you believe the author could better express their idea in their native tongue, clarity is not the issue. 4/10

Conferences use ‚Äúclarity‚Äù as a factor of evaluation to assess how well a paper is organised and how well it informs the reader. Some clarification in the next tweet... 3/10https://t.co/iQRRwEy98q

Suggestions to improve the quality of English are always welcome and constructive, 1) when preparing a manuscript, 2) as minor comments and 3) as editorial corrections after acceptance. The sore point is the importance of English as a decision factor in science publication. 2/10

As an AC for global conferences @icmlconf, @iclr_conf, @NeurIPSConf, I take issue with reviews that factor the quality of English in the score (even when done tactfully), and write back to reviewers. Suggesting specific language improvements as ‚Äúminor comments‚Äù is OK for me. 1/10

uBiome is a stain on the scientific community. Unfortunately, it is unlikely to be the last. (12/12)

Are their data valuable? Given the extent of their fraudulent practices, it is reasonable to assume the data they produced are questionable. After all, the founders clearly did not care about the data, the customers or the science. (11/n)

To no ones surprise, Dr. Almonacid stated they had not completed ANY research to support their claims. uBiome‚Äôs recommendations included FMTs for a range of conditions outside of the FDAs FMT approvals. (10/n)https://t.co/kc4LjEetJN https://t.co/Kpb8GkGmTE

During a meeting in 2018, with microbiome experts from across sectors present, their VP of Research (Dr. Daniel Almonacid) was asked if they had performed the research to support their actionable claims. (9/n)
They supported their claims by citing papers, which did not use their kits, lab or bioinformatic processing, and which often used different methodologies. (8/n)

Separate from whether uBiome should have asked for and collected this type of information, uBiome made regular false claims about actionable results without evidence. They actively encouraged people to ‚ÄúTake action.‚Äù (7/n)
So where are these data now? uBiome sold their data to a company outside of the United States, it is unclear if the PHI went with the sale. (6/n)https://t.co/tVkaiJYSTO

uBiome no longer exists, so are these data still a concern? Yes. uBiome‚Äôs privacy practices stated that they ‚Äú‚Ä¶do not intend to sell [Protected Health Information]‚Ä¶‚Äù. (5/n)https://t.co/SH93DG9l3o https://t.co/XBtlQtw0d8
These questions were presented irrespective of your age. The screenshots were taken after telling uBiome I was 6 years old. (4/n)

The sexual history prompts encouraged subjects to answer invasive questions. Answers here could put a person in legal jeopardy in some countries. This information puts lives at risk. (3/n) https://t.co/GAWwEJHrOj

uBiome had an IRB protocol in place approved by E&I Review Services (website appears defunct). This review board, which presumably approved their questionnaires, allowed questioning human research subjects about their sexual history in detail. (2/n)https://t.co/ofik0PRDhW https://t.co/aMolaElMJj
The focus on uBiome‚Äôs fraud is important, but we should not forget about the unethical scientific practices they pursued. (1/n)

Here are some numbers. Using the greedy algorithm on 19 dimensions you see memory drop from 71Mb to 14Mb and time drop from 3.7s to 2.4s for the exact same solution. With the A* algorithm you see memory drop from 1433Mb to 711Mb, but time increases by a lot. https://t.co/AdLJPwZu27

The algorithm works by making "parent graphs" for each variable, which are trellises that contain all combinations of parents. The score is calculated for each parent set and if a subset of parents gives a better score, that is propagated onward. See this Yuan&Malone(2011) fig. https://t.co/8GjeyYHjJq

Diseases that come from several genomic variants and environmental factors are called complex, or polygenic diseases. An example of one of these is coronary artery disease. People with this disease tend to have 60+ of the same variants that are spread across the genome. https://t.co/kYgYiEHnwh

These variants can have a lot of influence on the risk of specific diseases. One way is when inherited diseases can be traced back to a single gene. An example of this is cystic fibrosis, a disease caused by variants in the CFTR gene. https://t.co/OspW6HmG0z

Areas I've fully cleared have not shown any regrowth even a few years later. They do recruit from bird-dropped seeds, but only slowly. Once an area is cleared, it only needs occasional scans to see if new plants have arrived. Any found must be eliminated.

With the smaller invasive trees, I simply remove them from the ground.Buckthorn almost always cannot grow back from roots, so cutting them below ground is sufficient. If you cut them at ground level, you have to herbicide treat the stumps, or they will grow back.
The more natives I can restore, the less room there will be for the invasives to get re-established.

This patch of woods was mowed field/lawn some 40 years ago. Some native woodland ephemerals had made it back on their own, but others had not.As I clear more and more of the European Buckthorn (Rhamnus cathartica) & Bush Honeysuckle (Lonicera morrowii or L. maackii) I fill in.
I've got two species of trillium, and a few other woodland ephemerals growing in a protected cage, so they can multiply up before being spread into the less protected areas of the woods.

We also organized all the previous literature of all species in both of these genera (about 50 species) into 2 large tables detailing all the host species and collection locations . That will make it a lot easier for people to work on these parasitic copepods in the future [6/6]

We could tell N. johndaveorum was a new species b/c it had 4 large spine-like structures in a row on its first appendage (feelers like the antennae of insects), along with some other differences [5/6] https://t.co/8Lm56l19nU

The other species we named Nothobomolochus johndaveorum which is latin for "John and Dave's species". That was our way of saying thanks to the fisherman John Page & Dave Thompson who gave us the fish we discovered this parasite on  [4/6]

We named the nostril copepod Unicolax longicrus. "Longicrus" is latin for long leg, which describes the long 4th leg of this copepod that made it obvious to us that this was a new species [3/6] https://t.co/pjBukvTnnT

These new species were collected with about 30 other new parasitic copepods (and hundreds of other parasite species) in a @UQ_News sponsored collecting trip in #Australia to survey #fish #parasites. One was found in fish NOSTRILS! [2/6] @AS_Para

So what really is the alternative to meritocracy, which is then also genetic meritocracy, and seen in a global perspective, a racial meritocracy?

At the same time, society at large benefits from this near-optimal allocation of labor quality to most desired work to be done. We could allocate jobs at random, but this would many society a lot less efficient, & require massive social coercion (essentially a form of communism).

Meritocracy simply involves the free trade of labor, and thus results in the most valuable labor being the best paid, in general. This then means that persons who were lucky to get good genes get rewarded with more money for their more useful labor.

Covariation provides clues of genome plasticity & the benefit of introgression for niche adaptation, but to address if genes are in epistasis it's necessary to test function. Here we show a functional link among covarying gene pairs with the use of formate as an electron donor.

The cj1168c mutant displayed significantly reduced FDH activity after growth with selenite in the low nM range (partially restored by genetic complementation). We therefore designated cj1168c as selF (selenium transporter for formate dehydrogenase). https://t.co/d01BN3blLF

A homologue of cj1168c in Cupriavidus metallidurans has been shown to be involved in selenite uptake. Therefore, FDH activities were measured for our cj1168c mutant andwt grown in minimal media with limiting concentrations of selenite or selenate. https://t.co/qPQXtOfIN0

As none of the mutants showed altered FDH activity in rich media, we considered that their function may be related to a FDH-specific nutrient requirement. FdhA requires a molybdo- or tungsto-pterin (Mo/W) cofactor and a selenocysteine (SeC) residue for catalysis.

The mutants and their parental wildtype were grown in rich media & their formate dependent oxygen consumption rates determined. cj1167 (ldh), cj1168c (selF) and ppi mutants demonstrated wt levels of FDH activity, while activity in both fdhD and modE mutants was abolished. https://t.co/JkPMNYxfX8

The FDH complex oxidises formate to bicarbonate to generate electrons that fuel cellular respiration. fdhD & modE have known functions in biogenesis of the FDH complex, so we constructed deletion mutants to investigate the role of these remaining 3 genes in FDH activity.

These putative epistatic links essentially occur across two loci in the genome (fdhD/modE and cj1167/cj1168c/ppi), with each of the latter three genes linked with both fdhD and modE. https://t.co/9V5HBzbDcZ

We hope the review will be a useful introduction to those measuring protein stability, and provide a starting point for extensions for systems that don't conform to the most simple analysis methods.

We also highlight the importance of choosing baselines, and attempt to put measurements of denaturant- and heat-induced unfolding into a common framework including describing approaches for global fitting of 2D unfolding measurements.
We also describe basic thermodynamic theory for heat-induced unfolding including how this can be studied by calorimetry or spectroscopy.

In addition to presenting the commonly use linear extrapolation model for denaturants, we also provide some historical background on the developments and thermodynamic theories leading to it, including Schellman's solvent denaturation model and theory for weak binders.

In all other cases (which, I hope, are reasonable enough expectations), I'd love to hear from you!I am very excited for giving research advice/mentorship, helping with code setup, and helping expand GNNs to new exciting areas! Please, feel free to reach out. (4/4)

Similarly, if you write an email asking me to help you deploy a GNN technique on a dataset I'd never heard of, **and** asking me to do all the data preprocessing (with a "solve my homework" kind of attitude), it's, again, very unlikely you'll get a reply. (3/4)

By this I mean, if you write a generic email to me asking for internships, which sounds as if it was just mass-sent to 100 researchers at once (one common way I spot this is if I'm referred to as a "Prof" :) ), I'm very unlikely to reply to it. (2/4)

I am very eager about email (& try my best to reply quickly), be it asking for advice, research discussions, talk invitations. My most exciting collaborations started by email threads.Just *please* try to make your email constructive, and actually address it to me. (1/4)

This is very concerning. What we don't know is if the weaker antibodies and the inherently harder to dodge T-cell immunity generated by vaccines still prevent disease (the easier thing to measure is neutralisation by antibodies).

The dark clouds here will be variants that potentially escape vaccine induced immunity. We already have one potential one - B.1.351 - the "South African variant" which clearly gets rid of the most common epiptope from other variants (B.1.1.7 included) meaning antibodies bind less

I don't want my positive positioning to somehow imply we are magically out of this - many things have gone wrong in many countries, and there is plenty of chances for making yet more mistakes, but we have a major, major new chess piece on the board.
(lots of this is deeply unglamorous stuff about logistics and supply in many places).

Alot of people want to view this through a politics/ethics lens - I get that - but I view this through a rates/logistics lens - we have enough vaccine for sure, now can we get the rates up this year worldwide to the right places.
This is quite a task (!) but the presence of easier cold chain vaccines (Ox/Az, J+J, Novavax) and massive production (eg, Serum Institute in India) means this is feasible. All credit to this system.

The foresighted work of @gavi means that this process - setting up the vaccine bridges to a better world is happening worldwide and both for fundamental ethics reasons and selfish trade and tourism reasons we want the entire at risk population in the world vaccinated

However, there is a big, big difference to Spring or Autumn 2020; EU countries know the vaccine bridge is being built, and having watched Israel and the UK walk over their bridges they will probably be able to structure the mid to end of their bridges better still.

I can't see a solution that doesn't require substantial tightening of NPIs - tighter lockdown rules. The precise mixture is for each system to work out (it is bamboozling complex to navigate) but basically - minimise indoor contact time is the major thing to achieve.

Nevertheless with a higher inherent transmission (probably due to longer infectious period) and a somewhat higher disease causing (frustratingly) of this variant means the task of keeping transmission down is substantially harder than the summer of 2020.

This has grown in complexity because of B.1.1.7 (the "English variant") has become, as expected, the dominant variant - this actually took more time than I expected from late December when this variant was first characterised fully from UK data with higher transmission properties

The UK has a staged relaxation process happening this spring/early summer - it seems likely this will work given the Israeli experience in front of the UK (though - we can still mess this up!). Frustratingly the EU has another set of months though to navigate the pandemic.
This is pretty much as good as one can ask for - in the UK showing both Pfzier and Ox/Az vaccines work well, and furthermore both the UK and Israel have high levels of the B.1.1.7 variant.

There are many more really cool (un)related efforts out there, most of which I have not had the chance to use (yet!). These include FILER (https://t.co/sSUEqeUCeb), ReMap (https://t.co/qJBNTDS0dC), GEMMA (https://t.co/BLIHKuh52H), GTRD (https://t.co/B3OluCFDx8), ... what else?

Importantly, most of these resources provide access to their data in simple matrix-like formats (i.e. biosamples-by-"features"), which is a HUGE help when trying to actually use the data for downstream analyses.

Perhaps most amazing (to me) from a scale perspective, are the efforts of harmonizing RNA-seq datasets, such as done by Recount2 (https://t.co/8rJvTdcfFD) and ARCHS4 (https://t.co/EeTJuE5Ump), the latter of which includes access to ~750,000(!!!) gene expression datasets. https://t.co/DDHlQmSVhn

Speaking of genotype information, some well-established resources are the 1k Genomes Project (https://t.co/FwRlOq2lot) and TOPMed (https://t.co/04a0GCGyPH), documenting 100M++ variants.For GWAS, @bmneale's processing of the UK Biobank data is invaluable (https://t.co/Cst7Xs8kmV)
Incorporating genotype information, and its effect on gene expression, the GTEx Consortium provides a fantastic resource:https://t.co/NhVThpaadL https://t.co/mbVP1aufl9

Of course I'm biased, but if you're looking for the most extensive set of annotated putative regulatory regions, take a look at our DHS Index and Vocabulary:https://t.co/8owz00vfK1 https://t.co/43gzxpksQq
Then there is the more recent EpiMap project, which combined ENCODE, Roadmap and others into one giant resource, and imputed any missing data:https://t.co/aPw1plgsND https://t.co/slGcFrgHyG
Focused more on epigenomic assays, uniformly processed across 100+ biosamples (incl. chromatin state data!), is the Roadmap Epigenomics Project:https://t.co/O8KnqinlJ1 https://t.co/Aj0ajsB8Lf
First there is the ENCODE project, which provides access to more than 16,000 genomic datasets across a wide variety of biosamples and assays:https://t.co/iYZT0ti6HK https://t.co/Tzu7bYledX

The value and interpretability of a genomic dataset increases greatly by placement into a wider context of large (uniformly processed) reference datasets.The ones listed below I've found to be most useful for my work -- I'd be curious to hear of others!https://t.co/cm01xbHK7k

This simplifies the common use case where we have concatenated variable-length values such as strings, with an sd_vector marking the starting positions for random access. With duplicate positions in the sd_vector, we don't need special handling for empty values.
I wonder what should be the proper semantics for operations on such "multiset bitvectors".

I noticed by accident that because sdsl::sd_vector uses Elias-Fano encoding, it is perfectly capable of storing duplicate values. Many bitvector operations continue to work, some involving unset bits break, and many traditional invariants no longer hold.

Despite these limitations, makes a strong argument for not routinely screening for ASB post 2 months after transplant.Authors provide an updated meta-analysis of relevant trials: https://t.co/kl0FI5KYMV

Limitations: Only applies to >2 months post transplant (and in fact most were >6 months). Wide CI for primary outcome, so cannot exclude smaller benefit (that arguably would still be clinically relevant).

In summary, biallelic rare/ low frequency deleterious (LoF) variants in #NOD2 account for 10-12% of all #CrohnsDisease cases, w/early onset of disease  (generally in teen years). We suggest NOD2 as a Mendelian gene for #IBD & genotype status to be a strong predictor for disease.

Now, #NOD2 is one of the 1st & most replicated loci by GWAS. However, GWAS mostly look at additive effects, so when we analyzed the cohort using genotypic & recessive models, we saw huge effect sizes compared to an additive model (OR=3.9-10.1). (6/n)

22/ Please also check out the outstanding work in @Cancer_Cell from @VanAllenLab #KevinBi @MXresearch @DrChoueiri about immune (and tumor) cell ‚Äúreprogramming‚Äù that takes place during immunotherapy in advanced RCC:https://t.co/cvJgc2Dba5

21/ Thank you to our many other close collaborators (@rafalab, @LabSignoretti, #ArleneSharpe, +many more), our funders (incl @CDMRP, DF/HCC Kidney Cancer SPORE / @theNCI). cc @KidneyCancer @kidneycan @IKCCorg @ScienceinBoston @dfcidatascience
19/ What‚Äôs next? We hope to examine if these interactions can be inhibited to restore immune function and, ultimately, see if they can be therapeutically targeted to help our patients with ccRCC

18/ Overall, these results support a model of progressive immune dysfunction with advancing disease stage, with exhausted T cells and M2-like macrophages forming an ‚Äúimmune dysfunction circuit‚Äù in later disease stages https://t.co/zUpX6ego8I

17/ We confirmed our findings in other publicly available datasets, in part using a gene signature for exhausted T cells ‚Äì TAM interactions. In multiple external cohorts, high expression of this interaction signature was associated with a worse prognosis, even within stage IV RCC https://t.co/X5YvMHqHrJ

16/ We confirmed protein-level expression of these ligands and receptors using high-dimensional flow cytometry, and confirmed co-localization of these two immune populations in advanced disease using multiplex immunofluorescence https://t.co/cnHqb6RXVP
15/ These exhausted CD8+ T cells and M2-like macrophages seemingly formed a bi-directional ‚Äúimmune dysfunction circuit‚Äù in more advanced disease stages https://t.co/B4HxPdMqSv

14/ What were these interactions? The TAMs made ligands for T cell inhibitory receptors (supporting T cell exhaustion), and the exhausted CD8+ T cells made factors that support M2-like polarization of TAMs https://t.co/dMvxdzqfKQ

13/ Exhausted CD8+ T cells and M2-like macrophages were both enriched in advanced disease stages, but did these cells talk to each other? We used #CellPhoneDB to infer cell-cell interactions, and inferred that these two populations did in fact communicate https://t.co/kQgof6UDAb
12/ When we looked at the macrophage branch, those from advanced tumors were late in pseudotime, had an anti-inflammatory phenotype and expression of ‚ÄúM2-like‚Äù markers https://t.co/T1zx7anaqi

11/ Macrophages can exist on a spectrum rather than in discrete states, so we again used trajectory analysis. An interesting pattern emerged ‚Äì classical monocytes branched into non-classical monocytes or into macrophages. There were clear differences between disease stages https://t.co/cn6bAYgrR4
10/ We then turned our attention to the myeloid compartment. Here too, we found that M2-like tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) were enriched in more advanced disease stages https://t.co/mMH1f4NkWD
9/ Linking clonotype to phenotype, we found that exhausted CD8+ T cells (enriched in advanced disease stages) also had a more restricted TCR diversity https://t.co/Yw5r0aGzxE

8/ Surprisingly, we found incredibly clonotype enrichment in some tumors. In one case, almost 50% of infiltrating T cells were all recognizing one target antigen. This is motivating our future work to uncover the relevant tumor antigens in RCC https://t.co/hrWY5H90Hv
7/ Next, through single-cell paired alpha-beta TCR sequencing of over 60,000 infiltrating T cells, we described the TCR repertoire and clonotype-phenotype relationships https://t.co/lVUJ3hdl50
6/ So what biological program was driving this trajectory? When we examined individual genes and gene programs, it became clear it was T cell exhaustion https://t.co/YueraiS9Ap

5/ Further, trajectory inference analysis of CD8+ T cells produced a mostly linear trajectory. We again saw an interesting pattern ‚Äì CD8+ T cells from normal tissue and early stage ccRCC were early in pseudotime, and CD8+ T cells from more advanced disease were late in pseudotime https://t.co/cPqRLV0YnH

4/ We uncovered transcriptionally heterogeneous infiltrating T cell populations, but they separated into two main groups ‚Äì exhausted CD8+ T cells and non-exhausted T cells. In advanced disease stages, there was a substantially higher proportion of exhausted CD8+ T cells https://t.co/mzrtdgrlo1

We are depending on the world for everything and it‚Äôs not that we can‚Äôt produce, we just choose not to... It is frustrating when there is a solution but you can‚Äôt scale it up. I think our leaders prefer the option of importing because of the kickbacks that occur in the process.

We should recognize that investing in research is very critical to development. If we don‚Äôt do it,  who will? If there is anything to learn from COVID-19 pandemic, it is that Africa is over-reliant.
The vaccine has been presented on several platforms in this country and across the continent but has not been implemented simply because of our mindset.

The Diagnostic test that we developed in the Centre is used in the United States but not in Nigeria. The vaccine is almost at the stage of implementation in the UK yet we refuse to use our own product.

It is typical of Africans to believe that anything from western countries is better. The vaccine candidate we developed for COVID-19 is already undergoing clinical trials in UK. They are accepting it but our own government would not. And, that is why we are still under-developed.

On buying Covid-19 vaccines from foreign countries: It is the choice of the Country; it is the choice of Africans. Africans still live in their colonial minds; they don‚Äôt believe in themselves and what they can do. They believe so much in buying and importing.

8/ You can also tag each work package with the teammate in charge of getting it done. When getting updates from a teammate, you can filter or query by name, and you have a list of work packages to discuss with them. Status tags (eg, done/ongoing) could also be used as a filter.

Ten lactating mothers who were members of the medical staff at Tel Aviv‚Äôs Ichilov Hospital and were vaccinated agreed to give samples of their breastmilk.

Most importantly, we are grateful to the patients who donated blood for this study. We hope our findings will help the early identification of the most vulnerable patients and lead to new therapeutic strategies for COVID and other acute respiratory diseases. (7/7)

This was an amazing collaboration with some phenomenal trainees (Monique van der Wijst, Sara Vazquez, George Hartoularos, Paul Bastard), a number of my science heroes (Mark Anderson, Joe DeRisi, Jean-Laurent Casanova), and the COMET & IMPACC consortia at UCSF. (6/7)

We also found an inhibitory molecule LAIR1 originally discovered to inhibit lymphocyte activation by Lewis Lanier at UCSF to be highly expressed in myeloid cells in patients with deficient interferon stimulated gene expression. (5/7)
18/19 patients who required mechanical ventilation, 4 of whom had autoantibodies against type-1 interferons, had deficient expression of type-1 interferon stimulated genes in myeloid cells. (4/7)

Utilizing multiplexed CITE-seq, we profiled > 600k PBMCs from 54 COVID-19 patients (15 negative controls and 11 healthy donors) and found that the expression of type-1 interferon stimulated genes is observed early during COVID that diminishes quickly during hospitalization. (3/7)

In > 4000 samples in San Francisco, we identified type-1 interferon autoantibodies in ~20% of critical COVID-19 patients and 0.32% of a community cohort in the Mission District. These estimates are remarkably consistent with those reported by the Casanova lab. (2/7)

Here's our preprint validating the frequency of type-1 interferon autoantibodies in critical COVID-19 and associating the presence of autoantibodies with deficient expression of interferon stimulated genes profiled using multiplexed CITE-seq: https://t.co/PNYgAqhnte (1/7)

21/21 And to end this thread, the valuation of Nightingale is.. Interesting. Many others have written analysis/thoughts about it. Including: @KauppalehtiFi, @JussiKarki, @Taloustaito, @kimvaisanen, @inderes

20/21 ‚Ä¢ The real disruption would be if they could enter the healthcare clinical diagnostics market. This could be worth billions. Unfortunately they have not been able to do it, and it does not seem to be on their strategy.

19/21 To summarize some of my thoughts:‚Ä¢ The technology is great and scalable. It works!‚Ä¢ The team is great, highly experienced professionals and I really like them!‚Ä¢ The DTC market is really challenging.

18/21 I have tried the customer product from Nightingale, and think it is cool! It has the usual challenges though, as most of the information it provides, is not really actionable beyond the usual: eat healthy, stop smoking, maintain normal weight, use alcohol in moderation.

17/21 The solution has been direct-to-consumer business model, which is tricky, not least because of the how burdensome taking/shipping samples is, even if it is a saliva kit or blood sample taken on a quick service stop.

16/21 The obvious choice for Nightingale has always been to replace the existing clinical diagnostics measurements all around the world. The tech has potential for this, but they have really struggled with it, without any real successes beyond pilots.

15/21 NMR is great for analyzing large sample collections, such as biobank/research collections. The question that everyone has been asking has been "how many research samples do we have in freezers around the world"? Nightingale has gone through a big portion of them already.
14/21 The guys working on the NMR platform also saw the potential, and span out a company of it. The company was originally called Brainshake, later changed to Nightingale Health.
13/21 I ended up analyzing several cohorts and clinical trials (tens of thousands of people) that utilized this NMR platform. This resulted in several other scientific publications.
12/21 We were impressed with the technology and our first publication using this tech was published in 2011: https://t.co/0B3x82DYbv
11/21 The idea being, that instead of doing 20 different analysis in clinical lab, why not run the sample through NMR and get hundreds of measurements with the same price. Makes sense right?

10/21 The folks working with the NMR platform made adjustments, and got the correlation to around 80-90%, which starts to be pretty great. The technology works, and I have verified this with my own independent analysis in a large cohort of clinical samples!

How long? Well that is very hard to predict, as we don't know the shape. But the kind of levels of evolutionary change accumulated so far are trivial. Ultimately it is an empirical question, and we should observe a slowdown in the apparent rate of evolution once this occurs. 5/n

But these evolutionary processes can take thousands of years. At the moment, SARS-CoV-2 is in the middle of this space and only gradually exploring the possibilities around it. I has a long way to go. 4/n

Imagine a host A and a host B. The virus has an evolutionary 'shape' defined by host A at transmission, and will adapt to the shape of host B. Eventually, yes, our model would predict that the host would constrain the evolution of the virus. 3/n https://t.co/zbN0Q19SbE

The problem is, this model and sort of evolutionary process is not applicable to the kind of timescales that we are observing, but rather far longer time periods, with questionable relevant to implications for public health right now. 2/n

Lots of talk about E484, and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 to its human host. The idea that somehow the evolution of the virus might be constrained by these mutations, leaving the virus 'trapped' is akin to the 'prisoners of war' model that we developed. 1/nhttps://t.co/72JXik4XG4

very good evidence dex saves lives; and f*** all evidence that HCQ has or does not have in vivo antiviral effect.I'm definitely not a HCQ true believer - but we really need these guidelines to make some sense

category 2 (massive uncertainty) and so I cannot reconcile this with their interpretation of the evidence (not much uncertainty).I feel this has everything backwards. Ie very good evidence HCQ does nothing in C-19 disease;

üßµ (3/6)Thank you to Dr Clare McCann at @NorthumbriaUni; Dr Sharon Glaysher at @portsmouthuni; Victoria Wright, Dr Nadine Holmes & Wendy Smith at @UniofNottingham; @dr_rachstanley at @NorwichResearch; Katrina Slater, Dr Angie Lackenby & Dr Kate Appleby at @PHE_uk üëèüëèüëè

The interpretation of "no important difference": "This difference was not important [..] because the intervention effects were negligible and/or very imprecise, for example confidence intervals that include both important benefit and harm"Clearly HCQ for prevention falls into

High quality evidence (e.g. HCQ does not reduce mortality in C-19 prevention) apparently means: "the authors believe that the true effect is probably close to the estimated effect". In the HCQ for prevention the estimated effect varies of 2 orders of magnitude...However...

The RECOVERY trial had 930 deaths out of 3883. The odds ratio for death was 0.82 (0.72-0.94). This was graded as "Moderate evidence with serious risk of bias".???Other problem with the WHO/BMJ approach to these guidelines. They are conflating certainty and utility

So how the heck does this endpoint get decided as "High quality evidence" that HCQ confers "No important difference in mortality"? That's bonkers - this is orders of magnitude underpowered to say anything of interest.Compare this to the same WHO guideline on dexamethasone:

Only 1/6 trials had deaths (Mitja et al): 5 deaths in HCQ arm (n=1116) and 8 deaths in control (n=1198). This gives the highly noisy estimated OR of 0.67 with a CI of 0.2-2At the lower end this would be a fantastically good drug - at the upper end this would be a killer drug!

This would suggest that the uncertainty around the primary outcomes of interest are very well characterised. Have they been for HCQ (or any drug) in prevention of COVID-19?The top outcome for the guidelines panel is mortality (separate debate whether this is right choice)

A recommendation *against* the use of a drug is very different from a recommendation *for* the use of a drug. The statistical analogy is type 1 versus type 2 error.This recommendation is basically saying that HCQ has either no effect or a negligible effect -> should not be used

The latest guideline from @WHO on HCQ in prevention of COVID-19, making a very strong statement about lack of efficacy & stating all research into HCQ should be stopped.My prior is none of these small molecule drugs will work - but this @BMJ_latest guideline is flawed üßµ https://t.co/cwHNeb0T21

Later that evening I walked over to my partners place a little while away, and I passed the same 3 cops, breaking up an altercation outside a strip joint. They waved, and said they wished they were still trying to solve the music puzzle.
We come back up, no music!Better yet, I'm still alive in my multiplayer game and my mates waited for me. We finished that game up, and it was a real blast.

After a few minutes, we decided that the best way to get the music to stop, was to turn the power off for her apartment, then back on. Saves the fridge, but kills the music. Strata lady gives us a key to the cabinet that controls the building power, and we execute out plan

Plans start being hatched between my other 2 neighbours and the cops. Climb over the balcony and try the doors? Usually open right? I could hack the WiFi and block the mac address to stop it. We could call a lock Smith? These all have legal implications, so we had to find another

She answers the second time. She is up. The coast, 100km away. No idea why there is music playing. We try to explain she may have started the music remotely with Google or Spotify, but she is a bit technology illiterate, so doesn't understand or know how to stop it.

Well, I open the door and am greeted by 3 cops, kicking the bottom of my neighbours door to get their attention, but there is no answer. I invite them to look over my balcony to see if anyone is inside. They can't see anyone.Lady from strata across the hall gives them her number

About 11pm, and I hear loud knocking. Really loud. So loud I thought it might have been my door. I was in the middle of a multiplayer game with my mates (risk of rain 2), hard to pause. I got to a safe spot, and told my mates I'll be back in a sec.

10pm comes around, and we are still at the same levels, but some how it is louder now that the other sounds of the surrounding area have dropped down.I stay up late so I've got a fair bit of tolerance for this kind of thing, and it was quite out of character of my neighbour.

Now to say it was loud, I really mean it. My phone on my desk was updating me with which songs were playing, with its auto song identification thingo, and I can feel the vibrations of bass sections. The day gets on, and around 8pm, it's still going hard. Surely slowing soon...

It was the day before Mardi gra, a Friday, and I figured they were just cutting lose, albeit damaging their ear drums in the process. Didn't really bother me with headphones on working, and given I've been up late playing rock band till 3am, I'm hardly one to go dobbing them in.

Living in the world of connected devices can be super helpful, but sometimes really annoying.The other night, around 3pm, I hear music start playing next door in my apartment block. It was pretty loud, and our walls are super thick, so it was really turned up.

8/8 The SARS-CoV-2 genome is ~30,000 bases, 1/100k that of the 3B bp of human.Sequencing a human genome is now ~$1k and SARS-CoV-2 ~$50. That's only 20x. So $/Gb is cheaper for larger genomes?Do these numbers make sense?If not, what could be the source of the inaccuracy?

7/ ‚ë£ The GridION will not be cheaper per Gb than a MinION (they use the same flow cell).Illumina machines (orange) and the Pacbio 8M Sequel II become cheaper at ~10^5Gb. Or ~35k human genomes.Could someone please confirm these numbers? https://t.co/mZFKdLBUPw

6/ The human genome is 3 Billion bp, so that's 3Gb, right? So between 10^2 Gb and 10^3 Gb is ~200 human genomes. Are my numbers correct?‚ë¢ The PromethION (blue) & Pacbio 64M chip R&D (black) is more cost effective between 10^4 and 10^5 Gb. So that's ~20k human genomes. https://t.co/6PKix8yDZK

5/ First question, until what point is the MinION the most cost-effective choice?- Using the Flongle will increase $/Gb ‚ë† Best for small genomes?- The Genapsys 144M chip (purple) will become more cost effective than a MinION somewhere between 10^2 - 10^3 Gb ‚ë° https://t.co/Qan0t6CqKo

4/ Another caveat: @albertvilella's data is on the human genome. I don't know the difference of $/Gb between sequencing human and viral genomes. I only have experience with the latter. Our actual material cost is ~$60/assembled whole genome of SARS-CoV-2https://t.co/PQEJ210IFT

H/t to @adamhamdy for spotting the preprint, I encourage those who have the time to read it, or to note the broader concepts. 13/n
"...in that they might have any combinations of increased transmissibility, altered virulence and/or increased capacity to escape population immunity." 12/n
"Whatever SARS-CoV-2 variants eventually summit that peak could be a considerably bigger problem for us than any variants that we currently know..." 11/n
"in April. Such outcomes could perhaps have even been predictable given the mounting selection pressures exerted by increasing population immunity in the latter half of 2020." 10/n

"Factoring in the time it would have taken for prototypes of these 501Y lineages to spread sufficiently from the index cases, their detection and characterization in the last three months of 2020 may have in fact been the expected outcome of chronic infections that started.." 9/n

"The chronic-illness-emergence-hypothesis hypothesis is also appealing because it explains both the high degree of divergence of the 501Y lineage viruses relative to their nearest ancestors, and the timing of their emergence." 8/n
"The precise cause of this selective shift is unknown but increases in seropositivity and/or the relaxation of transmission prevention measures are obvious candidates." 7/n

"Our discovery here of a major selective shift in the evolution of SARS-CoV-2 variants sampled before and after November 2020 appears to support the possibility of a sudden global SARS-CoV-2 fitness landscape change in approximately October 2020." 6/n

"Taken together, these patterns of detectable selection suggest that the adaptive value of signature 501Y lineage RBD mutations may have only manifested after a selective shift that occurred shortly before November 2020." 5/n

"...viruses in all three lineages may be climbing very similar adaptive peaks, and, therefore, that viruses in all three lineages are likely in the process of converging on a similar adaptive endpoint." 4/n

"Why did the heavily mutated 501Y lineages all arise on different continents at almost the same time? Was this due to an intrinsic property of SARS-CoV-2 and its mutability changing, or was it a shift in the host selective environment extrinsic to the virus?" 3/n

Its also beautifully written, and I hope the authors will indulge me in posting some key quotes from the paper, that capture some of the main messages. Of course, I encourage you to read the whole thing. 2/n

We will continue to monitor all variants and all genomes uploaded to GISAID for potential interference with the assay performance. As part of our ongoing communication, an FAQ is being prepared for  the #LamPORE web page: https://t.co/sDuWk5XcUr 9/9
As LamPORE #COVID-19 does not assay the #SARSCoV2 spike gene, mutations in this region do not impact its performance. 8/9

A maximum of 2 mismatches were observed for B.1.351 (South Africa), P.1 (Brazil), and P.2 (Brazil) genomes, representing 0.1%, 0.8%, and 0.4% of the uploaded genomes for each SARS-CoV-2 variant, respectively. No mismatches were found for A.23.1 E48K. 7/9
For the B.1.1.7 E484K lineage, one out of the 44 uploaded genome sequences has a single mismatch. 6/9 https://t.co/jtTVKP3bB9

For all available B.1.1.7 (UK) genomes as of 25 Feb 2021, 5% have one mismatch and very few have two or more mismatches. Our analyses reveal no impact of these mismatches on assay performance. 5/9 https://t.co/0EqKxSkrd0

9.7% of uploaded genomes during this period have one mismatch across all 24 primers. 0.7% have two mismatches and very few have more than two. We also examine where in the primer the mismatches occur. 4/9 https://t.co/yhxB2Py3Ki
Table shows mismatches for all 24 #LamPORE primers (eight primers per targeted region) against all whole #SARSCoV2 genomes uploaded to GISAID from 26 Jan to 25 Feb 2021. 3/9 https://t.co/HpwFGSYnzo
We are pleased to report that our analyses indicate that #LamPORE performance remains unaffected by all known #SARSCoV2 variants and strains. 2/9
Under post-market surveillance, we continually monitor the potential impact of new #SARSCoV2 variants on the performance of our rapid and highly scalable #LamPORE COVID-19 assay. 1/9

It is one of the nicest and oldest memories I have.Photo Source (https://t.co/JB6PRBF3Mp)

Turns out it wasn‚Äôt a river but a small tiny stream made from the small hole people use to fetch water from underground. The stone ‚Äì which is the only stone- is still there. The only fact here is it was not a big river but a small stream and it wasn‚Äôt unsafe.

Every time I asked about this memory, mum could not remember that moment but she said she would take us with her to wash or fetch water if we were awake and wanted to leave the compound. As an adult, I saw the river which hasn‚Äôt changed much.
I felt good being in the middle of the river and my feet on a smooth stone.

I was standing on a stone in the edges of a big river. Between me and the land was only a place my mum could help me move to. She was there. She put me there after lifting me off using my underarms as support.

I was later told that inside was my grandmother and my aunties who were feeding my cousins and had told us to go out of the house. We had to wait for our mother to come back so that we can something to eat and make us warm.Second Memory: Good
We leaned against a muddy wall that I can‚Äôt remember its color. We had no sweaters on. We were cold and hungry. Inside that house were people talking, can‚Äôt remember about what.

As a 2-3 year old girl, I remember watching drops of rain dig into the earth creating fresh holes while others dug into the previously created holes from huge drops of water from the roof. Where we were standing was dry and dusty with red soil.
My first time going to kisii as an adult after 16 years was very profound because it made most of my memories very clear.First Memory: Bad

No one can be an expert in everything. Therefore the most important skills a bioinformatician can have are learning and communication skills: you need to work in a team with experimental or clinical researchers. You need to document your work and master tools as they're needed.

It's a very demanding field. You need to develop many programming skills but also understand the mathematics and statistics involved in what you are doing. It's not easy to keep up with new tools and understand biological context, of sometimes many projects and collaborations.

Things are improving but there aren't many clear paths to become a bioinformatician, despite widespread demand. We've all got a different story but this is too familiar. I strongly believe learning on the job but we need to think about how to get new people involved. https://t.co/Vx6MXfqqbt

This is important because it has been argued that CBB's reproductive system is functional haplodiploidy (kind of similar to the reproductive system in bees), and this presumptive Y-chromosome challenges that hypothesis.To learn more, read:https://t.co/ni9P4nBbuX https://t.co/cED0LG3p2i
Finally, genomic and cytogenetic evidence reveal the presence of a putative Y-chromosome. https://t.co/W1QElnxxQ7

Some of these alternative strategies or different sex-specific biological roles can be explained by differences in the expression levels of chemosensation-related genes of the coffee berry borer. https://t.co/799E9jn3Xg

CBB needs coffee not only for food. They build tunnels inside the beans where they mate and develop. Virgin females leave the bean and fly, but males are wingless and never leave. Therefore, ‚ôÇÔ∏ès and unrelated ‚ôÄÔ∏ès are obliged to find each other inside the bean where ‚ôÇÔ∏ès were born https://t.co/1giYb5vTJG

Thus, the evolution of this small chemical repertoire may explain why coffee plants are an exclusive host for CBB. Also, this finding offers future possibilities for exploration of olfaction-based control strategies. https://t.co/wf39j3PQsZ

More specifically, the chemical receptor repertoire is small among all the different families of chemo-sensory receptors. Including: odorant receptors (ORs), gustatory receptors (GRs), ionotropic receptors (IRs) and odorant-binding proteins (OBPs https://t.co/kAFPmABakM
First, we found that CBB has less number of gene annotations that are associated with chemical and sensory receptors when comparing to other species of beetles. https://t.co/s9j3cuinmP

Recently, we published a wonderful article in @SciReports  in which we analyzed an improved genome assembly of the CBB, and brought novel insights to old questions regarding this important and awful pest https://t.co/2ts6vNhQWM https://t.co/ymwLTRAxrr

We focused on developing a better understanding of the reproductive and sensory biology and genetics of CBB. And we decided to use genomic tools before they were cool, and cytogenetic tools after they were cool. https://t.co/VYGTodsiMJ
Indeed, that's a younger version of me and  @JuanValdez studying cytogenetics of the Coffee Berry Borer https://t.co/2uk0emQ7JJ

Some years before I started my PhD, I had the fortune to join an outstanding team of researchers (including: @lucionavarroe Eric Hernandez and other brilliant scientists) led by Pablo Benavides at Cenicafe, the center of Coffee Research in Colombia. https://t.co/ZtwVb8iL7u

In order to control this pest, the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia has developed the CBB integrated pest management (IPM) program. Not only at the agronomic scale, but also at the basic research scale. They invest many resources to study the biology of this bug https://t.co/vCxaMuUgA6
It is estimated that this beetle causes over 500 million USD worth of crop loss annually. https://t.co/GROy7Cfnzl
The Coffee Berry Borer (Hypothenemus hampei) is a curculionid beetle that despite being smaller than a sesame seed, it causes a huge damage to coffee production. https://t.co/d36ubQzo1G
But Colombia and many other countries in the Coffee belt have been struggling with a despicable pest: The Coffee Berry Borer (CBB) https://t.co/XESlPIzbNH

12/12 I just realized that when Neo learned Kung-fu, he still had to practice it. It was just a different interface‚Äîelectronic vs biological‚Äîbut still the biological brain had to change.You won't learn Roam-fu just by importing a JSON. You need to practice in the dojo! https://t.co/U5gjIBfKHp

11/ How do we take advantage of this specialized language we speak, Roaman, as a tool for teaching?- indentations shaping relationships between blocks- when should you use page references, block references, embeds and aliases?How do we serve both Roam novice and expert?

10/ As we have seen in #RoamSummit, there are many styles of executing workflows in Roam (Roam-fu üòé)I should explain the principles of a tool first and ask the user how they would implement it in Roam, before I show my style.https://t.co/saCFQKNrj5

9/ One of my favorite learning techniques is the Feynman method: explaining what (I think) I learned to someone else. This is one key reason why I tweet.I should encourage the user, in each chapter, to screenshot parts that resonated with them and explain it somewhere.

8/ The war stories must themselves have a clear teaching objective.I've been weighing whether to share actual stories from a slightly technical project (which requires some background): https://t.co/LI5l3LFagnOr a simple theoretical project as an example: eg a concert.Both?

7/ This book shares a craft rather than academic abstractions. Instead of books, the sources are experiences expressed through a simple framework.I've been deliberating whether to share war stories. They might be fluff. Maybe optional sections?https://t.co/EtNe2WyD0L

6/ Strong opinion on links: external links should be zero or near zero, page and block references should be minimal. These are distractions.The user could easily google external links. Page linking should be done by the user. This is part of making this rBook a Matrix dojo.

5/ @samuelbars has some interesting suggestions here. How do we apply this to this rBook?CYOA. I should create a guide. There are tools that should be done first.SRS. This rBook teaches skills more than concepts, so maybe N/A.https://t.co/Naw9U5kea5

We found that the pathologist evaluations were all clustered around 0, indicating that there was no difference in preference between our predictions and those of the annotators. This represents the first time a tissue segmentation algorithm has reached human performance. 4/5 https://t.co/Qpnv4IjSmP

In fact, this accuracy was what motivated us to perform what I think is one of the coolest analyses of the paper: a head-to-head evaluation by certified pathologists, where we blinded them to the origin of different segmentations and asked them to pick the more accurate one. 3/5 https://t.co/TsGGXceLqm

One of the most exciting things about Mesmer, our new algorithm, is that it allows us to accurately capture tissue morphology. When we applied it across a range of tissue types, it was easy to see that it was accurately capturing the underlying makeup of these distinct cells. 2/5 https://t.co/rsOny9IRfH

11/ Women are a hugely underserved market, despite having higher spending habits and greater levels of engagement than men. There's a preference for puzzle games, which companies like Playtrix may benefit from.
10/ Demographic shifts will split the gaming industry. Gen-Z have a preference for mobile and ad-revenue based models while Millenials show preference for nostalgia and console gaming.
9/ AR games remain nescient but expect rapid growth once the pandemic ends, especially as newer iPhones have embedded LiDAR scanners which AR heavily benefits from. Niantic is a clear market leader.
8/ Hyper-casuals are still maturing and there have been recent litigations. We may see this market more heavily regulated, though I expect them to continue to grow as they benefit from vitality.

Using external single-cell RNAseq data, we conclude not only cell-type proportions but also cell-autonomous changes may contribute to this divergence-convergence pattern. All these support the notion of loss of cellular identity with ageing. (4/4)

Reversals lead to gene expression divergence across tissues in development, followed by a convergence during ageing, confirmed in other mouse and human data. We show tissue-specific genes lose their expression or non-native tissues start to express non-specific genes. (3/4)

Building on our previous work reporting gene exp. reversals in the human brain during ageing, we study reversals in 4 tissues of mice & find ~50% but tissue-specific reversals: exp. trajectories in development do not necessarily continue to ageing (2/4)

So excited to share our latest work (with @hmtzgi, Khaitovich lab and @CompEvoMetu). Studying gene exp. across #mice lifespan, we show tissues diverge during #development but start to converge back during #ageing! Details üëá (1/4)#aging #transcriptomics https://t.co/zuSVy3Gx4b

E.g. for liquid biopsy, one may get around 10-20ng of DNA from a 10-20ml blood draw, which at the moment means PCR-based preps for all main #NGS systems.
So if your application where to benefit from, say, a Q33 better than a Q31 modal base-calling, first ask yourself: have I got enough DNA for a PCR-free prep?
More importantly, any PCR-based method devised so far also erases #epigenetic marks, which can only be read in conjunction with the 4-base alphabet if it's from a PCR-free method.

As we approach Q30+ on now 4 competing platforms, 2 short read and 2 long read platforms, it's a useful reminder that only PCR-free preps benefit from high quality base-calling, as any PCR-based method incorporates errors wrt the original material. https://t.co/5d35cfoR1O
