Also grateful for insightful comments and feedback from @AlainChedotal, @CamLBerthelot, @huguesrc, & @Warrier_Varun ‚Äî Hope those results may interest @JJHublin @ProfSimonFisher @WiringTheBrain, people at the @AllenInstitute & @BroadInstitute, and other curious minds!

That's all folks! üôè Special kudos to my co-author and genetic mentor @ThomasBourgeron, Simon Malesys for the amazing website, the @GHFC_lab for the support, and the scientists of the @InstitutPasteur, especially Lluis @QuintanaMurci & his team, J-P Changeux, and @DDiGrego_Neuro https://t.co/5uzRc9Dg4N

12/12) All the data are open & interactively explorable through a dedicated website: https://t.co/TubakYsaYsüíù In bonus the annotated variants, Neanderthal introgression, @AllenInstitute Brain data, and all links to key DB/website for medical genetics! https://t.co/RmG8fNDOlI

11/12) ... and in the end, we even identified genes specifically diverging in Homo Sapiens and Neanderthal/Denisovan, but conserved in other primates (e.g. ASXL1 AHI1 CNTNAP4  FAM111A & KIAA0319)Note: many other results are buried in the supplementary materials... https://t.co/0aU16Hah4H
10/12) Comparing Homo Sapiens with Neanderthal or Chimpanzees, we can see that some of those genes are divergent for Homo but less in other primates. https://t.co/0stjCRSiYL

9/12) Those cell types are expressing cilium markers and those genes have been associated with Joubert Syndrom, a rare genetic disease characterize by strong morphologic alterations (especially in the cerebellum). https://t.co/tYindAugAO

8/12) Using other #scRNAseq datasets, we then compared the signal of those ‚Äúciliated cells‚Äù from the cerebellum to cell types in the human cortex. The signal converge on DNA damage response genes associated with microcephaly in humans (e.g. BRCA1 NHEJ1 TOP3A RNF168) https://t.co/vR4rySdRHi

7/12) Using single-cell RNA sequencing, we uncovered that, indeed, in the cerebellum, one type of cell seems highly divergent. According to the original authors, the cluster they called ‚Äúciliated cells‚Äù was of a mysterious kind. https://t.co/SniysIzhfJ

6/12) Then, using the @AllenInstitute data, we investigated if there was still a divergent substructure at a finer anatomical level. It appeared to be the case, in the cerebellum! https://t.co/iNqxXewJMX

5/12) Focusing on highly conserved and highly divergent protein-coding genes in the brain, we observed that those associated with brain disorders tend to be more conserved too, especially for autism and intellectual disability. https://t.co/vwuQSWPCTY
4/12) We also observed that anatomical structures like Cerebellum and surprisingly the Prefrontal cortex are on average more conserved than the rest of the brain. https://t.co/uAQzB68aDK

3/12) Focusing on protein-coding genes specifically in the brain, we uncovered that such conservation of the nervous system is especially associated with genes functionally implicated at the synapse (not necessarily highly expressed) https://t.co/afs4Gb6FNf

2/12) Then, combining those data with public datasets such as the @Illumina Bodymap & @AllenInstitute Atlas, we looked across body tissues and biological functions and confirmed that genes encoding brain-related proteins are among the most conserved of the human proteome https://t.co/DCeEyhmGPa

1/12) This all started with the computation of the evolutionary pressures acting on virtually all human protein-coding genes (N=17,808) based on their divergence from early hominins such as Neanderthal/Denisovan, and non-human primates https://t.co/S7vcY3BmVK

With news of poor uptake of Ox/AZ in EU and worries about vaccine snobbery over J&J in USA, I think more countries should be looking to delay 2nd doses of the mRNA vaccines. It's a strategy that really looks smarter and smarter every day.

But if you set the 2nd dose dates of all vaccines to be roughly similar (12 weeks in the UK case), then you lose a lot of the 'pickiness'. Regardless of the vaccine, you'll be around 80% protected in the immediate future and then 90% protected later in the year.

All 3 vaccines, and the J&J too are actually all very similar in protective effects after the one dose. What makes one seem better than others is really just the speed of getting 2nd dose. I can totally see why individuals would turn down J&J or Ox/AZ in favour of an mRNA one.

The 2nd reason is vaccine 'pickiness'. If you get Pfizer/BNT or Moderna in US or EU, you're getting both doses within weeks and on paper will be 90% protected in 5 to 6 weeks. For Ox/AZ you have to wait 12 weeks for dose 2 and so you're not up to 90% levels for 1/4 of a year.

And with some proof now that vaccinations stop transmission, the more people vaccinated then the slower the spread of new cases. This first reason alone should be enough for other countries to consider this, but there's a second good reason too...

The first is obvious... you can get vaccine into more people from the start, giving 80% protection to 2x people vs. 90+% to 1x people. This clearly looks very nice in world vaccination comparison graphs https://t.co/WO4JmK1oSG

With lots of great real-world data now on the effectiveness of delayed 2nd vaccination dose, I'm kind of surprised other countries aren't immediately switching to the approach we have here in the UK. It has 2 very clear benefits.

Three. While I love the MDT discussion here, we have to remember that this is a public space and not a closed meeting. Our titles bestow a particular weight to our opinion‚Ä¶ and all it takes to plant the seed of doubt is uncertainty. Delayed vaccination is in nobody's interest.

Two. The goal of vaccination is to reduce morbidity and mortality and preserve health system resources. We are watching the evidence-base evolve in real time, and the data is dynamic. But what the public needs is a message that is jargon-free, opinion-free and consistent.

One. Vaccination is in the interest of the individual (‚Üì morbidity and mortality) and the community (sparing health system resources). Our Code of Conduct supports health advocacy, and every speciality college considers it an attribute of their fellows.

This last one was where I once had someone say "ideas don't matter" when it was clear their idea was not panning out as reasoning for continuing to pursue it; which is why I prefer "ideas are cheap" to "ideas don't matter"

I also use the expression "ideas are cheap" to kill off projects that don't seem to be panning out: "yes, this seemed like a good idea, it's not panning out; you need a new good idea"("Kill Your Darlings", but for ideas)

As a scientist I am not desperate for research ideas; and the vast majority of the papers I read explore/implement ideas that "were in the water" (this applies to the papers I write too) by adding legwork (and many small ideas)

Some examples in the post (clubhouse, bicycles), both seem to fit this model: they the result of an iterative process where a series of small ideas accumulate rather than one Big Idea that was just better(OTOH, PageRank was one Big Idea that was just better)
I think that point 5 in the linked post is exactly what I mean by "ideas are cheap": you will need many many small "ideas" to get from your Big Idea to success

17x/bonus: What's also interesting about meme plays (e.g. SPACs) is you can effectively proxy market forward looking fear in the low liquidity highly speculative meme names (e.g. SPACs great example). They tend to rally harder than the market and fall harder in times of duress.

To more novices like me (lol), the fixed income market is much larger and more liquid than the equity market. If a liquidity crunch happens there the equity market is toast, no matter what options hedging magic occurs.

Oh, and we'll be releasing more modules over the next few weeks. So stay tuned!

All of this is to say that while researching the topic I was humbled by the amazing science üß™ happening in real-time during this ongoing public health crisis and hopefully this module makes a useful contribution, however small.

Those links included in Module 1.4 are even more helpful because we expect them to updated regularly as science learns more about current and future variants. I won't even be offended if you skip by blabbering ü•± and jump straight to the linked resources.

Which seems like a good time to point out that all our modules contain more than just recorded presentations; each also includes a selection of articles üì∞ and resources for further information and (soon) example data for hands-on analysis üßë‚Äçüíº.

Because there's certainly no shortage of materials -both science and opinion- written about the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants. And it started to feel like an obvious gap in our line-up of modules planned for the toolkit that we had to address.

So instead of describing the variants, we focused on providing useful background info about genetics, evolution, the confusing nomenclature, and potential implications for genomic epidemiology. In doing so, hopefully we provided some value.

This topic is rapidly evolving (ü§ì) and was intimidating to approach given the wealth of information already in circulation. We knew our format couldn't keep up with the field (or the variants themselves), but we also knew our target epi audience had lots of questions ‚ÅâÔ∏è. https://t.co/zhFVtU7nvO
